text: Digging through Canon’s patent filings at the Japanese Patent Office has paid off once again. We’ve uncovered documentation showing Canon’s efforts to reduce the impact of high temperatures on lens elements. The goal? To keep video footage sharp and maintain high image quality, even in extreme shooting conditions. In patent application JP 2025-054037, published on April 7, 2025, Canon states its aim is:“To develop a zoom lens with a high variable power ratio and exceptional optical performance across a wide wavelength range.” In plain terms, Canon is working to eliminate image distortion—specifically chromatic aberration—in super-telephoto zoom lenses caused by environmental heat. The Solution To solve this, Canon carefully engineered how the lens groups interact. It starts with a positive first lens group (U1), which stays fixed during zooming— think of it as the anchor of the system. Then come two movable lens groups (U2 and U3): U2 has negative refractive power and moves to adjust magnification. U3 also moves and helps correct the image plane, keeping focus sharp throughout the zoom range. Next, there’s a fourth group (U4) behind them. This group includes the aperture stop (S) and a mix of lenses — at least one positive and one negative. Canon fine-tuned this section using a specific ratio between the distances from the aperture to the image plane and to the object side of the lens. This ratio, called Dfs / Dri, is kept between -0.10 and 0.24 for optimal performance. Canon also carefully selected lens materials that balance Abbe numbers and partial dispersion ratios — technical terms that describe how glass bends different wavelengths of light. This precise control helps suppress chromatic blur across the full zoom and spectral range. Why it Matters The result is a high-power zoom lens that delivers sharp, clear images—even in tough lighting and hot environments. Canon’s patent promises three major improvements: Sharper images in both daylight and low-light conditions. A broad range of uses, from video camcorders to security cameras. Up to 20x optical zoom with minimal distortion. While none of the lens designs in the patent are aimed at mirrorless cameras, this technology could find its way into Canon’s professional video lineup—think XF605, XA70, XA65, or XA55. html:
Digging through Canon’s patent filings at the Japanese Patent Office has paid off once again. We’ve uncovered documentation showing Canon’s efforts to reduce the impact of high temperatures on lens elements. The goal? To keep video footage sharp and maintain high image quality, even in extreme shooting conditions.

In patent application JP 2025-054037, published on April 7, 2025, Canon states its aim is:
“To develop a zoom lens with a high variable power ratio and exceptional optical performance across a wide wavelength range.”

In plain terms, Canon is working to eliminate image distortion—specifically chromatic aberration—in super-telephoto zoom lenses caused by environmental heat.

The Solution

To solve this, Canon carefully engineered how the lens groups interact.

  • It starts with a positive first lens group (U1), which stays fixed during zooming— think of it as the anchor of the system.
  • Then come two movable lens groups (U2 and U3):
    • U2 has negative refractive power and moves to adjust magnification.
    • U3 also moves and helps correct the image plane, keeping focus sharp throughout the zoom range.

Next, there’s a fourth group (U4) behind them. This group includes the aperture stop (S) and a mix of lenses — at least one positive and one negative.

Canon fine-tuned this section using a specific ratio between the distances from the aperture to the image plane and to the object side of the lens. This ratio, called Dfs / Dri, is kept between -0.10 and 0.24 for optimal performance.

Canon also carefully selected lens materials that balance Abbe numbers and partial dispersion ratios — technical terms that describe how glass bends different wavelengths of light. This precise control helps suppress chromatic blur across the full zoom and spectral range.

Why it Matters

The result is a high-power zoom lens that delivers sharp, clear images—even in tough lighting and hot environments.

Canon’s patent promises three major improvements:

  1. Sharper images in both daylight and low-light conditions.
  2. A broad range of uses, from video camcorders to security cameras.
  3. Up to 20x optical zoom with minimal distortion.

While none of the lens designs in the patent are aimed at mirrorless cameras, this technology could find its way into Canon’s professional video lineup—think XF605, XA70, XA65, or XA55.
